content.div:
He's starred in such small-screen hits as SCTV and Saturday Night Live. He's graced the big screen in Three Amigos and Father of the Bride. And he's taken to the stage in The Goodbye Girl and Little Me. Now, you can add celebrity judge to Martin Short's resume, as the Canadian entertainer joins the inaugural season of Citytv's Canada's Got Talent. Just after the news was announced Thursday, we sat down with the humble icon to chat about his new endeavour.

Q: What convinced you to do the show?

A: It was an exciting offer, something I've never done before. The idea of going to different Canadian cities, seeing raw talent in a fascinating stage of their career get up with their hearts pounding and perform, it's kind of exciting.

Q: What do you hope to bring to the program?

A: My own unique, kind of subtle brilliance, coated with modesty.

Q: Out of the broad range of performers on the show - comedians, contortionists, magicians - is there a talent in particular that already intrigues you?

A: No, I'm not prejudiced toward one talent over another. Anyone who is great at something, it's exhilarating (to witness). You cannot be a fan of an opera, but if Pavarotti walked in - well, first of all you'd be amazed because he's no longer living - but, were he living, and walked in and hit a high note, even a non-fan of opera would start to cry.

Q: How does a nice guy from Hamilton handle a contestant who bombs?

A: With a sweet smile, you tell them to get out.

Q: What is your criteria for a performer to come out on top?

A: Well, I guess their talent - if they're good.

Q: Any qualities in particular, such as showmanship or technicality?

A: It's all those things. You can have an amazing range as a singer, but (your) voice just isn't interesting. Some of our favourite singers don't have perfect voices, but they have perfect soul that combines with soaring notes. So you do need elements of all those things.

Q: As a judge you will be giving contestants showbiz advice. What's a great piece of advice you've received in your career?

A: I don't know the answer to that question, but I certainly have learned, which takes a long time, to not take it personally. To just treat it like a business and do absolutely the best you can, at the time.

Canada's Got Talent will air in March 2012 on Citytv.
